Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms and Moderators of Victimization Continuity: The Role of Observed Friend Interactions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. This postdoctoral fellowship award supports the training and research of a young scientist studying the interpersonal consequences of childhood exposure to family aggression in different relationship contexts. The project also incorporates methodological diversity, relying on longitudinal self-report data, coded observations, and daily diary data, which allow for examining critical micro- and macro-level interpersonal processes. Although past research shows that victims of parental aggression are at increased risk for experiencing victimization and/or exhibiting aggression in the context of their peer and romantic relationships, it remains unclear how and why exposure to family violence increases risk for future victimization and aggression. In order to interrupt these maladaptive cycles of violence, it is important to identify the underlying mechanisms that account for the stability of victimization over time and learn about potential protective factors that can buffer victims from enduring interpersonal difficulties. The current project seeks to delineate the interpersonal characteristics of youth with a history of victimization by directly examining adolescents' observed social behaviors in discussions with a close friend.

The specific aims of the current project are to examine a) how a history of family victimization influences adolescents? interpersonal style (e.g., affect, behavior) within a dyadic, friendship interaction and b) whether observed maladaptive interpersonal functioning with friends can account for the continuity of victimization over time (e.g., from family to dating partners). By studying victimization longitudinally, across different relational contexts (e.g., family, peer, and romantic partner), and using a range of methods (e.g., self-report, observational coding, daily diary), the proposed study has the potential to advance both methodological and theoretical approaches to studying antecedents and consequences of interpersonal violence. In addition to examining maladaptive interpersonal functioning as a key mechanism implicated in the continuity of victimization across different contexts, the project will investigate the buffering role of social support for adolescents with a history of victimization, relying on both lab-based observed interactions with a friend and daily diary reports. By considering interpersonal relationships as involving dynamic processes-unfolding through both moment-to-moment interactions and gradually over time?the project will offer unique insight into how peers can serve as both a source of stress and resilience across childhood and adolescence. Additionally, identifying the specific factors that maintain versus interrupt victimization stability is hoped to offer increased understanding of how to develop targeted intervention and prevention strategies among youth at risk for or experiencing interpersonal aggression.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With funding from the National Science Foundation Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship, Dr. Hannah Schacter spent two years after graduate school expanding her research and professional training. The overarching project goal was to study developmental continuities and discontinuities in young people's experiences of interpersonal stress, with a particular focus on adolescent exposure to aggression across family, peer, and romantic contexts. Within this research agenda, Schacter also sought out training in innovative methodological and statistical approaches and conducted research using multi-modal assessment, including daily diaries, ambulatory physiological monitoring, and lab-based behavioral observations. As one innovative methodological accomplishment, she developed a novel observational coding scheme to characterize the way adolescents talk to their friends about age-relevant social issues (e.g., dating). She also utilized experience sampling methods to understand when and why adolescents' everyday social experiences contribute to their well-being and incorporated physiological measures to evaluate how interpersonal stressors "get under the skin" to influence young people's health.

A number of important findings have emerged from the project, and several are highlighted below. At the broadest level, this research underscores the importance of studying adolescents' interpersonal experiences and developmental outcomes across multiple relationship domains simultaneously. Youth are embedded within various family, peer, and eventually romantic contexts, and this project highlights that adolescents' experiences across each of these domains can independently and interactively contribute to their overall adjustment. For example, findings from a daily diary component of the current project demonstrate that adolescents who lack support from their friends on a day-to-day basis are less likely to feel unhappy or lonely if they feel supported by their parents. This suggests that support within the family context can compensate for an absence of support within the peer context. Schacter also found similar evidence of compensatory processes in another dataset, wherein adolescents who were rejected by classmates during middle school were more likely to show maladaptive outcomes in their high school romantic relationships (e.g., aggressive and unsupportive behavior), but they were protected from romantic dysfunction if they had high quality friendships across the high school transition. Even at a biological level, Schacter's other findings demonstrate how everyday social experiences can confer both risk and protection for young people. Specifically, results from the project show that, on the one hand, daily interpersonal stress (e.g., victimization by friends) can prompt dysregulated physiological (e.g., cortisol) responses; on the other hand, experiences of interpersonal intimacy, as documented within lab-based behavioral observations and young people's daily social experiences, can attenuate physiological reactivity (e.g., skin conductance; heart rate) and promote emotional closeness.

The current project fulfills the NSF intellectual merit criteria by capturing a dynamic view of adolescents' social relationships across multiple levels of analysis: from moment to moment, day to day, and year to year, and from the social, to the psychological, to the biological. By illustrating when and how interpersonal experiences--both positive and negative--with family members, peers, and romantic partners shape adolescents' trajectories towards or away from maladjustment, the project offers insights into both acute and more global risk and resilience factors. Correspondingly, the project's emphasis on capturing synergistic interactions across relationship contexts and different time scales offers several broader impacts. From an intervention and prevention perspective, it is critical not just to understand that exposure to violence and other forms of interpersonal stress contribute to youth maladjustment, but when and how. This project highlights multiple potential avenues of intervention, such as increasing opportunities for compensatory social supports, that may help interrupt maladaptive cycles of relationship difficulties, particularly among socially vulnerable youth. Additionally, as part of the project, Schacter expanded the reach of her findings beyond the scientific community, conducting radio interviews, consulting with media outlets, and writing public opinion pieces to increase research accessibility to public stakeholders. Additionally, given that the project provided many opportunities for student involvement with research activities, Schacter engaged in mentorship and professional development with undergraduate, postbaccalaureate, and graduate students throughout the duration of the project.
